question.name: q1
question.text: Rate the overall performance of this resident.

option.description: Not at PGY-1
Attending (Aspirational)

question.name: q2
question.text: Handoffs: This resident completes safe, thorough and comprehensive handoffs. The handoff is consistently thorough, informative, concise and communicated effectively.

option.description: Handoffs are not performed
Handoffs performed at the level of a PGY-1 resident.
Handoffs performed at the level of a CA-1 resident.
Handoffs performed at the level of a CA-2 resident.
Handoffs performed at the level of a CA-3 resident.
Handoffs performed at the level of an attending physician.

question.name: q3
question.text: Patient Care: The resident performs an adequate preoperative history and physical, identifying all of the patients co-morbidities as they relate to the upcoming anesthetic and appropriately review and interpret labs and other studies (echocardiogram, PFTs, etc) as they relate to the anesthetic.

option.description: Not at PGY-1
Performs general histories and physical examinations. Identifies clinical issues relevant to anesthetic care with direct supervision. Identifies the elements and process of informed consent.

Identifies disease processes and medical issues relevant to anesthetic care. Optimizes preparation of non-complex patients receiving anesthetic care. Obtains informed consent for routine anesthetic care; discusses likely risks, benefits, and alternatives in a straightforward manner; responds appropriately to patient's or surrogate's questions; recognizes when assistance is needed.

Identifies disease processes and medical or surgical issues relevant to subspecialty anesthetic care; may need guidance in identifying unusual clinical problems and their implications for anesthesia care. Optimizes preparation of patients with complex problems or requiring subspecialty anesthesia care with indirect supervision. Obtains appropriate informed consent tailored to subspecialty care of complicated clinical situations with indirect supervision.

Performs assessment of complex or critically-ill patients without missing major issues that impact anesthesia care with conditional independence. Optimizes preparation of complex or critically- ill patients with conditional independence. Obtains appropriate informed consent tailored to subspecialty care or complicated clinical situations with conditional independence.

Independently performs comprehensive assessment for all patients. Independently serves as a consultant to other members of the health care team regarding optimal pre-anesthetic preparation. Consistently ensures that informed consent is comprehensive and addresses patient and family needs.

question.name: q4
question.text: Patient Care: Resident formulates an appropriate anesthetic plan, taking into account the anesthetic options (MAC vs GA vs regional), surgical procedure, and patient’s co-morbidities. The resident is able to carry out this plan and easily adapt it, if necessary.

option.description: Not at PGY-1

Formulates patient care plans that include consideration of underlying clinical conditions, past medical history, and patient, medical, or surgical risk factors. Adapts to new settings for delivery of patient care.

Conducts routine anesthetics, including management of commonly encountered physiologic alterations associated with anesthetic care, with indirect supervision. Adapts to new settings for delivery of anesthetic care.

Formulates anesthetic plans for patients undergoing common subspecialty procedures that include consideration of medical, anesthetic, and surgical risk factors, and that take into consideration a patient’s anesthetic preference. Conducts subspecialty anesthetics with indirect supervision, but may require direct supervision for more complex procedures and patients.

Formulates and tailors anesthetic plans that include consideration of medical, anesthetic, and surgical risk factors and patient preference for patients with complex medical issues undergoing complex procedures with conditional independence. Conducts complex anesthetics with conditional independence; may supervise others in the management of complex clinical problems.

Independently formulates anesthetic plans that include consideration of medical, anesthetic, and surgical risk factors, as well as patient preference, for complex patients and procedures. Conducts complex anesthetic management independently.

question.name: q5
question.text: Patient Care: Resident performance in crisis management.

option.description: Not at PGY-1
Recognizes acutely ill or medically deteriorating patients; initiates basic medical care for common acute events; calls for help appropriately.

Constructs prioritized differential diagnoses that include the most likely etiologies for acute clinical deterioration; initiates treatment with indirect supervision and seeks direct supervision appropriately.
Identifies and manages clinical crises with indirect supervision; may require direct supervision in complex situations.
Identifies and manages clinical crises appropriately with conditional independence; assumes increasing responsibility for leadership of crisis response team.
Coordinates crisis team response.

question.name: q6
question.text: Patient Care: Residents should be able to evaluate and manage a patient's airway. In addition, they should be able to anticipate and prepare for a difficult airway.

option.description: Unable to recognize airway patency.
Recognizes airway patency and adequacy of ventilation. Performs bag-valve-mask ventilation with assistance.

Recognizes patients with a difficult airway but may need assistance with evaluation and management. Applies knowledge of the American Society of Anesthesiologist difficult airway algorithm to prepare equipment and supplies for airway management. Performs basic airway management in patients with normal airways including endotracheal intubation, supraglottic airways, and videolaryngoscopy. Recognizes need for assistance and/or equipment and seeks help.

Prepares appropriate equipment and supplies for the management of difficult airways including cricothyroidotomy. Performs advance airway management techniques including awake intubations, fiberoptic intubations, and lung isolation techniques.

Identifies and corrects problems and complications associated with airway management (ex: hypoxemia during one lung ventilation, sudden drop in ETCO2) with conditional independence. Manages all airways, including special situations (trauma, loss of airway) with conditional independence.

Independently assesses and manages the airway for all clinical situations using appropriate advanced airway techniques including cricothyroidotomy. Independently supervises and provides consultation to other members of the health care team for airway management.

question.name: q7
question.text: Patient Care: During their general anesthesia rotation, residents are expected to perform machine checks, understand the need for more invasive or special monitors in additon to the standard ASA monitors, and interpret the data correctly.

option.description: Recognizes the standard ASA monitors.

Demonstrates the correct use of standard monitoring devices including blood pressure cuff, ECG, pulse oximeter, end tidal CO2, and temperature monitors. Interprets data from standard monitors and recognizes artifacts.

Performs equipment and machine checks before each anesthetic. Inserts invasive monitors like arterial lines and central lines under direct supervision. Utilizes ultrasound in challenging line placements including peripheral IVs and arterial lines. Correctly interprets data from invasive monitors. Recognizes and appropriately troubleshoots malfunctions of standard ASA monitoring equipment and anesthetic machines.

Understands indications for invasive monitoring, and inserts arterial catheters with conditional independence and central lines with indirect supervision. Applies data from advanced monitors with indirect supervision. Recognizes and appropriately troubleshoots malfunctions of advanced monitoring equipment.

Obtains vascular access in complex or difficult situations with conditional independence. Supervises other members of the health care team in the placement and interpretation of monitoring techniques. Recognizes equipment malfunctions and troubleshoots appropriately.
Independently selects and uses basic and advanced monitoring techniques. Teaches other members of the health care team including junior residents placement of invasive monitors.

question.name: q8
question.text: Patient Care: This resident demonstrated procedural skills for obtaining vascular access appropriate for the following level of training.

option.description: Not at PGY-1
Able to reliably place peripheral IV catheters of varying sizes as necessary for venous access.

Inserts arterial and central venous catheters with direct supervision. Demonstrates use of ultrasound for placement of invasive catheters. Recognizes and appropriately troubleshoots malfunctions of standard ASA monitoring equipment and anesthesia machines

Inserts arterial catheters with conditional independence and central venous catheters with indirect supervision. Performs advanced monitoring techniques for assessing cardiac function (e.g., pulmonary artery catheterization, transesophageal echocardiography) with direct supervision. Recognizes and appropriately troubleshoots malfunctions of advanced monitoring equipment.

Obtains vascular access in complex or difficult situations with conditional independence. Performs advanced monitoring techniques for assessing cardiac function (e.g., pulmonary artery catheterization, transesophageal echocardiography) with indirect supervision. Supervises other members of the health care team in the placement and interpretation of monitoring techniques. Recognizes equipment malfunctions and troubleshoots appropriately.
Independently selects and uses basic and advanced monitoring techniques.

question.name: q9
question.text: Medical Knowledge: This resident possesses a fund of knowledge and is able to apply knowledge to clinical situations appropriate to the level of training indicated below.

option.description: Lacks basic knowledge of common medical and surgical problems.
Demonstrates basic knowledge of the pathophysiology of common medical and surgical problems, but needs supervision in applying that knowledge to the perioperative patient.

Demonstrates knowledge of the pathophysiology of common medical and surgical problems and is able to apply that knowledge in the OR. This resident is able to come up with a plan and backup plan, but still requires close supervision while taking care of patients.

Demonstrates knowledge of the pathophysiology of more complex medical and surgical problems. This resident is able to identify anesthetic plan tailored to the specific needs of the patient and understands existing evidence in the literature to support the approach. Able to come up with alternative approaches and justify risks and benefits.

Demonstrates knowledge of the pathophysiology of highly complex medical and surgical problems. This resident is able to identify anesthetic plan tailored to the specific needs of the patient and understands existing evidence in the literature to support the approach. Able to come up with alternative approaches and justify risks and benefits.

Has the knowledge to function independently as an anesthesiology consultant; this includes knowledge of pathophysiology of disease processes and their anesthetic implications and knowledge of national guidelines and their applications in the perioperative area.

question.name: q10
question.text: Professionalism: This resident is a role model and team player to peers and medical students regarding professional choices and behaviors at the training level of:

option.description: Not yet achieved Level 1
Complies with institutional policies and regulations, including work schedule rules.

Acts as a reliable team member, recognizing the impact of one’s own work responsibilities on the institution and on one’s colleagues. Volunteers to assist colleagues, when appropriate, to cover illnesses/absences in order to ensure quality patient care.
Serves as a resource and counselor to medical students regarding their professional choices and behaviors.
Serves as a resource and counselor to junior residents regarding their professional choices and behaviors.
Models responsibility and accountability in one’s professional choices and behaviors.

question.name: q11
question.text: Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Residents should be able to interact with other healthcare professionals and advocate their plan for the patient in a knowledgeable and professional manner.

option.description: Does not communicate effectively with other team members; handoffs are not appropriately detailed. Medical records are incomplete. Does not do well with conflicts.

Basic communication does exist between resident and other team members; however more detail is needed. Handoffs are more detailed but still lacking in overall plan. Does not engage in behavior that breaches patient privacy. Is able to utilize existing resources for conflict resolution. Can mentor medical students.

Communicates with confidence regarding patient care to other team members. If required, the resident can provide detailed information from various sources to ensure adequate handoff. Documentation is concise and clear within the medical record. Can utilize existing resources for conflict resolution. Is able to mentor residents and medical students.

Can adapt communication to various scenarios (eg. Emergencies, Trauma, etc.). Can function as an extension of the anesthesia team with regards to providing consultation to other services. Can mentor junior residents and medical students as well as other APPs.
Can communicate with confidence in even the most critical situations. Is someone who can be trusted to resolve conflicts between others.
Is a mentor to all team members and can communicate on a consultant level with other physicians/APPs.

question.name: q12
question.text: Practice-Based Learning: Residents should be able to effectively teach and answer questions regarding the anesthesia plan in general and in specific as well.

option.description: Resident is able to converse in general terms with the patient, family and other healthcare staff regarding the anesthesia plan. Is able to acknowledge their own limits and ask for assistance from their seniors.
Can adequately explain the anesthesia plan to patients, families and other healthcare staff. Is able to teach basics of anesthetic management to students and other healthcare professionals.

In addition to explaining the anesthetic plan itself, the resident can explain risks, benefits and alternatives of most anesthetic plans to patients, families and other healthcare staff. Is able to teach general anesthesia concepts to other students, residents and healthcare professionals.

Can explain the anesthetic plan succinctly and clearly to others. Can also provide detailed information regarding risks, benefits and alternatives of general and subspecialty anesthesia. Can teach anesthetic concepts, including subspecialty care, to other students, residents and healthcare professionals.

Can independently function to provide consultation and education to patients, families and other healthcare professionals with only the most minimal supervision. Is also able to participate in discussions within the anesthetic community and medical community at large. Is able to provide detailed teaching regarding more esoteric topics within anesthesia as well.
Can function as an expert educator in anesthesia for patients, families and other healthcare professionals. Is able to educate the medical community at large about anesthetic topics.

question.name: q13
question.text: Overall assessment for this time period. Based on the resident's current level of training (e.g. CA1, CA2, CA3), I feel that this resident:

option.description: Did not meet expectations
Met expectations with concerns
Met expectations

question.name: q14
question.text: Please write any comments, concerns, or recommendations you have for this resident.
